复数的物理意义-电路中的理解：
利用能量守恒的观点，实数代表了真实的能量消耗，虚数代表了能量的存贮：
1、电阻：真实的消耗能量，所以为实数。
2、电容：把能量暂时存储在电场中，没有消耗，需要时能量可以释放出来，用虚数标识。
3、电感：把能量存储在磁场中, 没有消耗，需要时可以释放出来，用虚数表示出来。
4、能量公式：KVA的平方= KVAR的平方 + KW的平方，仍然可以看出，虚数代表了存储的能量。
- 绳子 于 2021年9月20日晚

Hello, Please help if you can.  I have an interesting problem for you. Let’s imagine we have perfect sphere. The radius of this sphere is 1m. The sphere is perfect mirror inside. The middle point of this perfect sphere is located at [0,0,0] point in x,y,z 3D space. There is also small hole on the surface of this sphere. This hole has the radius of 1mm and it is located on z axis. So the initial coordinations for the center of that small hole is [0,0,1]. Now let’s imagine we have one photon that can live forever, there is no loss of energy in this experiment. This photon is moving with the constant speed of 300 000km/s. Now the fun part starts. Let’s imagine the photon is enter through the small hole our sphere perfectly aligned with z axis. So it is entering through the middle of the small hole. It is bad decision for him as the sphere is also moving but in special way. Just after the photon enter the sphere , our sphere is rotating instantly of the angle alpha. The rotation has always the same pattern. The angle alpha is constant and equal 1deg, always the same directions but always only in one axis x or y or z. The first rotation is 1deg around x axis. Now our photon is inside the sphere and just travel to opposite side of the sphere so the distance is 2m. Photon hits the mirror and bounce back perfectly but the sphere now instantly rotates 1 deg around y axis this time. Our photon continue its travel and move 2m back but there is no hole there anymore. It is surprised because he likes to leave the sphere but he must bounce again and this time the sphere rotates instantly around z axis. This cycle is repeating many times. Now the questions 1. How long our photon will be trapped inside the sphere? 2. What will be the total length of the path of our small hole movement when the photon will escape? Can you do it? You can share this problem if you like.

I was thinking about that myself some time ago. We are first introduced to a math concept/apparatus in terms of what it IS and later what it DOES . In reality it's better to introduce it by a specific example of said concept, saying what it can do and giving not so accurate "definitions". And later you can teach that there are other kinds of those things and that the previous definition wasn't as good as the one given now. Finally at the end you give the true formal definition of what it IS
Essentially work bottom-up; not top-down

Pro photographer here. The phone is more than enough for what you're doing. No, really! Camera tech today is ... extremely advanced, and certainly enough for a talking head. So we're talking about diminishing returns here. There's really no big benefit in buying a better camera than what's on your phone - or, well, at least if it's on an iPhone or equivalent - for heads up work. It's a high quality mini camera. The only caveat is if you're doing real cinematography. If you're doing nature films. If you're doing some kind of art. Then, possibly , consider a better camera, that captures more details, or where it's possible to express yourself better, because of more doodads (yes, I really called it that!). But other than that, it's not really needed. The phone camera gets the job done, so use it!

Structuring Math explanations
- Concrete before Abstract
- Give examples first, then theory
- Be aware of abstractions:
- Topic choice > production quality.
- Content is king, how you produce it is secondary.
- Choose wisely, needs to be fresh
- But no 0 production quality though. Good sound a must.
- Be niche
- Choose something rare, esoteric
- Cant compete with other million videos.
- Build small, loyal audience
- May appeal to more than what you think.
- Know your genre
- Be upfront about your level, discovery mode
- Helping others, tutoring mode
- Slow/Fast? Don't follow others as is
- Definitions not at the beginning

Please consider my plug here: do some "anti-math" in macroeconomics. Academic macroeconomics (at least the three main schools: neoclassical, Austrian and new-Keynesian) is full of lengthy papers with boringly correct math but which is completely inapplicable to the real world and in fact outright hazardous to humanity (if you are poor or unemployed, opposite if you already have wealth). When you do such an explainer you can start amending the record with mathematics that is applicable, such as starting with MMT or following on from Prof Steve Keen. If you are a math geek with a social conscience this could be possibly the most valuable sort of contribution you can make to humanity.
That's because if there is ever going to be a green economic transition it will have to use an understanding of MMT, there is no other way. If politicians do not understand the mechanics of the monetary system (i.e., MMT) they will forever be acting like neoliberals and using the false "household budget" analogy, in effect tying their shoe laces together, with the consequence that those who can least afford it bear all the burden when governments shrink their net spending.
Even some microeconomics models and options pricing models (Black-Scholes) are full of correct mathematics, but utterly fail in the real world (witness the collapse of LTCM). A series of explainers why mainstream economists get so much so badly wrong would be incredibly useful to the humanities and popular financial/postcapitalist economics. The point is, it is not just because "the world is complicated," a lot of their errors are because they just have the understanding of the monetary system all backwards, whihc is like over 150+ years of professional malpractice in academic economics (they get paid to be wrong essentially). A good place to start is John Blatt's book Dynamic Economic Systems, which I can offer a nice PDF-LaTeX electronic copy of to anyone who writes to me (for educational fair use) --- on gmail I am "achrononmaster".
Another rich source of mathematical statistics useful in economics and risk analysis is Nassim Taleb's work, much of which is free online. (Taleb made so much money exploiting fat-tails and uncertainty he does not need donors.) For example, Taleb has a good overview of why cryptocurrencies have become scams and ponzi schemes (useful because he as an early booster of bitcoin, so it is pretty significant he changed tune). But although Taleb writes fairly well, he can be a tad obscure and assumes too much background (a lot of finance-trader jargon, none of it too complicated but it is off-putting when you are not steeped in trading jargon), so a 3b1b type explainer here would be valuable.

I'm not quite the kind of person you're looking for with this project, mostly because I am not new at this, but you inspired me to share something I've been cultivating in my brain for a few years.

I make video game speedrun explanation videos that break down world records and tool-assisted speedruns in full detail so that someone with a very basic understanding of what the game is can follow along and understand every detail that makes it possible. At first glance, it may seem pretty far removed from math, but the way I do it delves deep enough into the inner mechanics of the game that there is some computer science, and there are some mathematical concepts like probabilities.

But my favourite element of it is a bit insidious: it gets people, most of whom are young adults and teenagers, to become more curious about truly understanding something they are interested in. One day, I would like to make a video essay about the resemblance between reverse engineering a video game and the real life scientific method, and about how getting involved in the former acts as an accessible, enticing teaser of what the latter entails. I honestly believe that getting kids and teens interested in reverse engineering a game they love contributes actively to planting the seed of scientific curiosity, and it should be considered as a valuable paraeducational tool. My problem is it clashes too much with my regular form of content to put on my main channel, so I don't know where or how I would publish it.

The first thing you need to spend your time/effort on is your content. The second is: The Sound. You don't need to spend money! If you do.. yeah.. Sound. But the equipment doesn't make the sound good - you do. If you're speaking in an empty classroom (echoes!), two or three feet from the microphone (too quiet compared to the echoes!), the sound will not be good. Get a heavy blanket or some carpet scraps from a local store or installer to cut down echoes from the floor. Hang a comforter to cover a wall, put some packing foam behind your mic so it wraps around the sides a bit. Talk as close to the mic as you can without hitting it, and without blowing into it (off to the side or just under your mouth is great!). Even a super cheap mic will sound better than the phone's mic a meter from you. Bluetooth headsets will work - you can fix any latency in the editing software.
And here's a big (and sensitive) subject: If you have a heavy accent or are speaking in a language you aren't super fluent in - Slow Down! I really wanted to get some info on a product, and found a video that looked to have everything I wanted. Then I started watching. The person had a heavy accent, was speaking fast, and was in an echo-y room several feet from the mic. I have a slight hearing loss, and the combination made the video unwatchable for me. And I shouldn't have to say this, and probably don't need to in a place where math is the subject, but... Stay Away from Offensive Language! If there are any words you've ever heard anyone refer to as "the (insert single letter here) word" - Just Don't. "Edgy" (the latest definition) topics should be off the table as well.

I'm a tutor and this is generally how the enquiries come in for lessons:
"Hello my name is Someone and I need lessons in maths?"
On that information alone I generally have to decide to take on the student, who could be;
a school student (lower or upper grade), an undergraduate, a home learner, a postgraduate or other professional, admission test etc.
I find out they are an undergraduate doing a resit for instance, ok
Next question I ask is:
"Maths, do you mean analysis, calculus, linear algebra, geometry, statistics what?"
"oh they tell me its some of Calc1 and Analysis"
Next question I ask is what is their assigned reading list, books etc?
Strange you might think these days, but as soon as they name the text book, I pretty well have narrowed down what they mean by a maths lesson.
When I give lessons I generally use a mix of Scribblar Pro (I pay for this) and Online Wolfram Alpha (free usually) as presentation tools.
So maybe I will do a video on how to present a solution to a students question with Wolfram! They never seem to have heard of this in their university course which I find shocking and an indictment to current pedagogy in maths education at graduate level.

flip the inequality

That definition thing is a big one... Most math textbooks are written kinda backwards. They postulate some definition and then list a bunch of theorems/properties with proofs that follow from the definition, and finally they throw a few examples. Where in reality, the math is usually discovered in the exact opposite direction.
First someone notices a neat pattern in some concrete example.
Then he searches a bit to see where that pattern might come from and where else it can be found.
Then he explores if and how that pattern may generalize.
And only then can we start thinking about definitions, because now we have thing or category of things that's worth delineating from other things that are not that thing.

If I don't know what are the reasons and motivations behind defining this thing, then why should I even care? It's like giving people a solution to a problem that they yet don't even know exists.

I think that what is most needed for people to really get the math, or anything really at this point is structure and work for the students.
There are a lot of good explainers of almost anything, like these conceptual explainers like you do, or very thorough university classes where you don't get any real sense of where the math applies, but you don't get a collection of useful transformations and problems to do. Without those things then don't really get to make that thorough connection in your mind, and you never really learn to apply anything yourself because you have no practice.
We have a lot of people who can understand things but can't do things with it, and who forget because things aren't consolidated in their memory - that's a shame.
I like the project regardless, since there are a lot of things that still need to be covered, and things that can be improved upon. Good luck!

Grant is a spectacularly great explainer, and he has produced and posted some of the most outstanding educational content on the internet.

There is much good advice in this video. This question does deserve a somewhat more direct answer, however: "Is it ethical to publish an explainer as a beginner?" Ethical? Definitely not, and definitely not helpful unless you are far enough past being a beginner on a topic that what you are posting is solid and accurate. Remember you are potentially taking the time of thousands of people, and an inaccurate explanation may cost many of those viewers additional time and confusion as they eventually figure out that you misled them (even if unintentionally). This does not mean you need to be an expert on every facet of the topic or have any particular credentials. Just have enough consideration for your viewers to stay within what you truly understand and post explanations only on points you know to be correct. Remember, your viewers will often not have enough knowledge to evaluate and separate the correct from the incorrect in what you say.

YouTube is filled with videos that do not heed the above. We do not need more of those. We do need more videos like those Grant has produced and posted. Don't be shy, but study, learn, and use Grant and other excellent explainers as your guide, then post.

As someone who's made some math-adjacent content, approached from the perspective of video games, these are all things I've really struggled to learn the hard way.

The hardest part of a making video for me, is not the production value, it's not even the custom visuals -- I like to think I'm decently good at that. It's all in the scriptwriting, it's breaking down the giant "web of information", of genuinely difficult, specialist, complex topics into something approachable by a general audience, that's also fun to learn about. And I don't know if I've really succeeded at that, but people seem to like the things I've put out so far, so, hey. If anything, I've gained a super big appreciation for the teachers and the educators who make it seem completely natural.

I really love the lesson of "how did you do it" really having no big secret. The answer is literally: just do it. All the things you're bad at, you'll improve by just doing it more, and getting that practice in. The only real secret is having some amount of passion. Either for the topic at hand, or for the art of teaching or filmmaking, since you won't get anywhere past your first draft script if you don't have a genuine love in some part of the process.

And even still, it's a lot of work, it is genuinely grind, and can often come out feeling unrewarding. I have nothing but respect for those who continue to persist regardless.

About 10 minuets in... from the concrete to the abstract. Reminds me of my high school teacher Mr. Breening (Tartan Highschool Oakdale MN). He explained that again and again we would approach a subject with the pattern, HOW WHY HOW. We would work some specific examples. Then prove a general theorem and then work harder examples. I owe much to Mr. Breening.

Couple questions:

1) Does it have to be a specific topic, or can it be something more abstract and generally applicable such as "This is my advice on how to study math in school"? I legitimately have thoughts and a system on that I carried all the way through engineering school. Or maybe "Let me drill into your head why you should ALWAYS show your units in science and engineering calculations, and it's more work to NOT do it." I'm just spitballing here, but these are immediate things that come to mind that I would want to proselytize to younger engineers and students vs. explanation of specific concepts. It's still math, but it's more how to learn than what to learn.

If it's going to be a specific topic, then I'm probably going to be in the "Let's pick something and learn it together camp."

2) We've got basically a month to do this, which is not a lot of time. I do not have even a toe in video production, and I don't have a website, wasn't planning on getting one, and haven't designed one in years. For those of us in the same boat, if we submit something non-video, can you...um...put it somewhere? Maybe in a dark corner of your website or someone else's website that would agree to host it. If I did one of these, I really do want to put my effort into working on where I want to go and figuring out how to get there. 10:10 THANK YOU!!!! Holy Christ I have been saying this for years. So tired of dealing with teachers and textbooks that decide to teach a subject by introducing the theory first, then going to the practical examples, because they say it's the "correct" way. Considering many of these theories took some of the smartest people in human history to develop them in the first place, I fail to see how starting with them while teaching is in any way shape or form "correct".

This gets even more frustrating when you realize that in many cases the practical problems you solve using these theories usually end up being fairly straightforward, if just a little tedious. I really do believe that in many cases if the teachers started by just working some everyday problems with the students, just so the students had some sort of grasp of what this theory is there to do, it would greatly help the students, because at the end of the day, most of these theories exist to solve problems. The teacher's job isn't to teach the theory, it's to teach the student how to solve problems using this theory.

Here's what I'll say. If you are interested in making videos, you need to leave the preliminary "information gathering" and "planning" stages as soon as possible. You will get sucked into that stage and convince yourself that you are making progress while you absorb information and plan, but you are not actually doing anything, you're just thinking about doing something.

You have to just upload videos. The progress and improvement comes along the way, not in a pre-plotting (read: procrastination) phase before you ever upload a single video. Just do it.

Oh, I have thoughts on Conway's Free Will theorem. But they're more philosophical than mathematical and I don't have time to submit a video. But, in short, they consulted a physicist and a mathematician, but NOT a philosopher. They assumed human free will and then concluded indeterminism. I do believe in human free will, but I don't think it is obvious and I find the logic circular.

I think it is an outstanding proof that, so long as there exist uncorrelated datasets, then determinism is wrong. Then, from that, I argue in favor of free will. I don't assume it.

It's hard to overstate how powerful it is when anyone can learn something they want just by searching online. In a thousand subtle ways, when these explainers exist, projects go faster, school becomes easier, and math-phobia becomes a little bit less common.

A lot of excellent lessons and intuitions stay confined to isolated classrooms, or worse, confined to some individual's head. It takes effort to make videos, or blog posts, and to put them out there. Here, we're hoping to offer a little bit of activation energy to anyone who has thought about doing something like this, but just never got around to it.
